Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Always show supported frameworks for packages" (#4598) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Today NuGet.org shows the frameworks only if there are dependencies in the packages.
Twitter thread: https://twitter.com/imperugo/status/899901309788225540

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet gallery UI should show target frameworks the package" (#4077) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Neither nuget.org nor preview.nuget.org show the target frameworks of a package. Consider a package that targets net40 and net45, but expresses no package dependencies. The gallery shows _no hint_ as to what projects the package might install into.

Even when dependencies are expressed, that's only a rough estimate, and can under express the compatibility of this package. For example, a package might take a dependency on NetStandard.Library when targeting netstandard1.5 but have no dependency for net40, and the gallery will only show netstandard1.5 on the page even though net40 is also a target. 

It seems like a super basic and critical trait of a package to be able to see on the gallery. Can it be added?

see also: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/2805

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: Move Search Service from .NET Core 3.1 to .NET 6" (#9149) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Related Problem

_No response_

### The Elevator Pitch

.NET Core 3.1 is EOL on December 13, 2022.
https://dotnet.microsoft.com/en-us/platform/support/policy/dotnet-core

We should move the Search Service to .NET 6 before that time.

### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Fix A11Y bugs" (#9148) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Summary of the changes (in less than 80 characters):

* Fixes the color of the links inside READMEs to enable more contrast
* Fixes the tabbing to the ReCaptcha box
* Removes the aria-required attribute from label elements

Addresses: 
* #9132
* #9133
* #9134
* #9114

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: Show only latest minor versions in the version list by default" (#9147) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Related Problem

Mature projects likely have a lot of versions published and the amount of choice of versions can be confusing.

### The Elevator Pitch

Change the package version list behavior so that by default it shows only the latest minor.patch versions for each major one (with an option to show all) as those are likely the ones users would want to install.

### Additional Context and Details

Compare current newtonsoft.json version list:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/102933/174849739-3466e6ec-ff70-417b-88b5-6fba6d9a6192.png)
with compacted:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/102933/174850506-9d72e765-ca5b-45be-aa26-659ea09f622d.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: Increase the page size of the V3 catalog" (#9146) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Related Problem

Currently, the V3 catalog on NuGet.org has a page size of 550. This has served us well for many years but, as the protocol demands, the catalog is append only so the catalog `index.json` will only grow as the number of catalog leaves accumulates. To slow down the `index.json` growth rate we can increase the page size.

This will give us more time to plan a fully scalable solution (e.g. https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7787).

The downloads.v1.json file is over 100 MB and still parses fine but the difference here is that the catalog index.json may be downloaded much more frequently (to poll for catalog commits). A smaller file is better.

### The Elevator Pitch

We should add the ability to configure the page size. It's a .NET constant right now of 550. We should increase it to a larger size. The value of 1650 seems to be working just fine in DEV for several weeks

### Additional Context and Details

We have an internal discussion [on Teams](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/message/19:d10cd9192de2492986fba3baeea3093c@thread.skype/1652468991222?tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47&groupId=ad34ac55-6785-4e7c-82c3-7ba405d30c3c&parentMessageId=1652468991222&teamName=NuGet&channelName=Server&createdTime=1652468991222).

The index.json size over time is here:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/174692360-048bc4e8-dc22-4a77-8acb-cc511f156bab.png)
(y = bytes, x = month)

We already have several jumbo pages from deprecations:
PageUrl | LeafCount | max_CommitTimestamp
-- | -- | --
https://api.nuget.org/v3/catalog0/page9598.json | 1728 | 2020-02-09 13:04:53.7647929
https://api.nuget.org/v3/catalog0/page10769.json | 1183 | 2020-08-20 19:28:36.8641381
https://api.nuget.org/v3/catalog0/page10770.json | 1134 | 2020-08-20 19:29:20.2945851
https://api.nuget.org/v3/catalog0/page12124.json | 997 | 2021-03-12 10:27:09.9984875
https://api.nuget.org/v3/catalog0/page10857.json | 839 | 2020-09-03 13:35:37.7371129

The change in index.json MoM (month over month) is here:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/174692474-68b819e8-9203-4ca1-b085-cd5e0c13eb69.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: NuGet Server API reterns right link only for lowercase packages  " (#11897) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Other/NA

### Product Version

NuGet V3 API

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

_No response_

### Repro Steps & Context

If the package name is **18.3.4-f-DTE-23727-0002** then the link will be formed like https://artifactory.***.***.com/artifactory/api/nuget/v3/***/registration/***/page/18.3.4-f-dte-23727-0002/18.3.4-f-dte-24705-in-0001.json
And as result, the link will not work as it's looking for package **18.3.4-f-dte-23727-0002**, not for **18.3.4-f-DTE-23727-0002** and response will be 
```
{
"count": 0,
"lower": "18.3.4-f-dte-23727-0002",
"parent": "https://artifactory.***.***.com/artifactory/api/nuget/v3/***/registration/***/index.json",
"upper": "18.3.4-f-dte-24705-in-0001",
"items": [],
"@id": "https://artifactory.dev.intapp.com/artifactory/api/nuget/v3/***/registration/***/page/18.3.4-f-dte-23727-0002/18.3.4-f-dte-24705-in-0001.json"
}
```
but must return result something like this: 
```
{
"count": 9,
"lower": "18.3.4-f-DTE-23727-0002",
"parent": "https://artifactory.***.***.com/artifactory/api/nuget/v3/***/registration/***/index.json",
"upper": "18.3.4-f-dte-24705-in-0001",
"items": [<9_ITEMS_HERE_TRUNCATED>],
"@id": "https://artifactory.***.***/artifactory/api/nuget/v3/***/registration/***/page/18.3.4-f-DTE-23727-0002/18.3.4-f-dte-24705-in-0001.json"
}
```
It does not work only if **lower** element has an upper case letter, for **upper** element it works anyway

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Provide solution for NuGet Error NU1012" (#11905) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "Cache DTE service in VS Solution Manager" (#11902) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
The DTE service is used quite frequently during the solution initialization (about once per project usually). 
This service doesn't change and as such it can be cached. 

This is another part of https://github.com/NuGet/Client.Engineering/issues/1374

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Avoid JTF.Run wrapped property retrieval, use async methods instead." (#11199) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: In particular focus is on https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/dev/src/NuGet.Clients/NuGet.VisualStudio.Common/IVsProjectAdapter.cs and everything related.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: Project PM UI Install button should disable when `null` version selected" (#11096) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

VS any

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

Due to a bug in WPF https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/issues/4929,
..NuGet sometimes allows selection of a null separator https://github.com/nuget/home/issues/11007 (see for repro steps).

In Solution PMUI, the Install button is disabled as expected.
Project PM UI is not disabled, but should be. Note that the action does not occur, but no info is given to the user.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49205731/127242611-d2d1bbe5-2607-4d7b-97bc-c56ecfd31536.png)


### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Filter out floating version with the correct version in the Updates Tab." (#9828) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: Currently floating versions display the minimum possible version in the Package UI showing that there is an available update.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Package Signing Verification Env variable value should be converted to upper case before for comparison" (#11876) at NuGet/Home
Opened issue "Microsoft Security Advisory CVE 2022-30184 | .NET Information Disclosure Vulnerability" (#62) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody: # Microsoft Security Advisory CVE 2022-30184 | .NET Information Disclosure Vulnerability ## Executive summary Microsoft is releasing this security advisory to provide information about a vulnerability in .NET 6.0 and .NET Core 3.1, NuGet (NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat version range from 3.5.0 to 6.2.0). This advisory also provides guidance on what developers can do to update their applications to remove this vulnerability. A vulnerability exists in .NET 6.0, .NET Core 3.1, and NuGet clients (NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat version range from 3.5.0 to 6.2.0) where a nuget.org credential could be leaked. ## Discussion Discussion for this issue can be found at https://github.com/nuget/home/issues. (TBD) ## Mitigation factors Microsoft has not identified any mitigating factors for this vulnerability. ## Affected software ### NuGet & NuGet Packages - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 6.2.0 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 6.0.1 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 5.11.1 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 5.9.1 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 5.7.1 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 5.2.0 version or earlier. - Any NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat 4.9.4 version or earlier. ### .NET SDK(s) - Any .NET 6.0 application running on .NET 6.0.5 or earlier. - Any .NET 3.1 application running on .NET Core 3.1.25 or earlier. ### How do I know if I am affected? If you have a NuGet.exe, NuGet package, or .NET SDK with a version listed in [affected software](#affected-software), you're exposed to the vulnerability. ### How do I fix the issue? To fix the issue, please install the latest version of .NET 6.0 or .NET Core 3.1 and NuGet (NuGet.exe, NuGet.Commands, NuGet.CommandLine, NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat version 4.9.5, 5.7.2, 5.9.2, 5.11.2, 6.0.2, 6.2.1). If you have installed one or more .NET SDKs through Visual Studio, Visual Studio will prompt you to update Visual Studio, which will also update your .NET SDKs. You can get the version of NuGet.exe by running the `nuget` command. You should see an output like the following: ``` NuGet Version: 6.0.0.280 usage: NuGet [args] [options] Type 'NuGet help ' for help on a specific command. To install additional .NET Core runtimes or SDKs: https://www.nuget.org/downloads ``` If you're using NuGet.exe 6.2.0 or lower, you should download and install 6.2.1 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.2.1/nuget.exe. If you're using NuGet.exe 6.0.1 or lower, you should download and install 6.0.2 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v6.0.2/nuget.exe. If you're using NuGet.exe 5.11.1 or lower, you should download and install 5.11.2 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v5.11.2/nuget.exe. If you're using NuGet.exe 5.9.1 or lower, you should download and install 5.9.2 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v5.9.2/nuget.exe. If you're using NuGet.exe 5.7.1 or lower, you should download and install 5.7.2 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v5.7.2/nuget.exe. If you're using NuGet.exe 5.2.0 or lower, you should download and install 5.2.1 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v5.2.1/nuget.exe. If you're using NuGet.exe 4.9.4 or lower, you should download and install 4.9.5 from https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/v4.9.5/nuget.exe. You can list the versions you have installed by running the `dotnet --info` command. You should see an output like the following: ``` .NET Core SDK (reflecting any global.json): Version: 6.0.300 Commit: 8473146e7d Runtime Environment: OS Name: Windows OS Version: 10.0.18363 OS Platform: Windows RID: win10-x64 Base Path: C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\6.0.300\ Host (useful for support): Version: 6.0.5 Commit: 8473146e7d .NET Core SDKs installed: 6.0.300 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk] .NET Core runtimes installed: Microsoft.AspNetCore.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.AspNetCore.App] Microsoft.NETCore.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.NETCore.App] Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App 6.0.5 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\shared\Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App] To install additional .NET Core runtimes or SDKs: https://aka.ms/dotnet-download ``` If you're using .NET Core 6.0, you should download and install Runtime 6.0.6 or SDK 6.0.106 (for Visual Studio 2022 v17.0) or SDK 6.0.301 (for Visual Studio 2022 v17.2) from https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet-core/6.0. If you're using .NET Core 3.1, you should download and install Runtime 3.1.26 or SDK 3.1.420 (for Visual Studio 2019 v16.9 or Visual Studio 2011 16.11 or Visual Studio 2022 17.0 or Visual Studio 2022 17.1) from https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet-core/3.1 .NET 6.0 and .NET Core 3.1 updates are also available from Microsoft Update. To access this either type "Check for updates" in your Windows search, or open Settings, choose Update & Security and then click Check for Updates. Once you have installed the updated runtime or SDK, restart your apps for the update to take effect. Additionally, if you've deployed self-contained applications targeting any of the impacted versions, these applications are also vulnerable and must be recompiled and redeployed. ## Other Information ### Reporting Security Issues If you have found a potential security issue in .NET 5 or .NET 6.0, please email details to [secure@microsoft.com](secure@microsoft.com). Reports may qualify for the Microsoft .NET Core & .NET 5 Bounty. Details of the Microsoft .NET Bounty Program including terms and conditions are at [https://aka.ms/corebounty](https://aka.ms/corebounty). ### Support You can ask questions about this issue on GitHub in the .NET GitHub organization. The main repo is located at [https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client). The [Announcements repo](https://github.com/NuGet/Announcements/issues) will contain this bulletin as an issue and will include a link to a discussion issue. You can ask questions in the linked discussion issue. ### Disclaimer The information provided in this advisory is provided "as is" without warranty of any kind. Microsoft disclaims all warranties, either express or implied, including the warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose. In no event shall Microsoft Corporation or its suppliers be liable for any damages whatsoever including direct, indirect, incidental, consequential, loss of business profits or special damages, even if Microsoft Corporation or its suppliers have been advised of the possibility of such damages. Some states do not allow the exclusion or limitation of liability for consequential or incidental damages so the foregoing limitation may not apply. ### External Links [CVE 2022-30184](https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2022-30184) ### Revisions V1.0 (June 14, 2022): Advisory published. _Version 1.0_ _Last Updated 2022-06-14_
